WHY WE BURNOUT .. AND HOW TO PREVENT IT OUR MINDS burnout because of sustained over taxing of its performance and coping capabilities.. We can train our minds to not only cope better as the pressure needle increases, but to actually thrive in this sustained environment.. To achieve this , we need to increase our CONTROL of our Brains control panel , our cues and triggers that signal discomfort. What you will learn to do is obtain control of cues that are out of your control , these overide your conscious mind, these will cause your tendency to üî• In our course advanced objective awareness this is the skill you will learn .. here is a snippet.. Gaining control of sub conscious cues that build tendency to burnout , stress , anxiety... Step one locating cues to overwhelm. Note there could be several cues and triggers to alter, and by altering these , you alter the information you tell your brain . Find the cue . These are found in our reactions and attitudes. let's start simple . Write down a reaction you have at work in a challenging situation....... now write down your justification for this reaction ................... These two form your conscious and BIASED , operating responses. These are feed from your sub conscious mind which you can change now . wrote down your why , why you feel justified to react that way ...... Think about this , explain as detailed as possible if you can but not necessary.. Your why is how your mind has been trained to see situations [your perspective] , work to change it , work to understand what it is in your WHY , you are resisting , not accepting. because if you do , your perspective will change and your minds perspective of the situation will move from a negative position to one which your mind can embrace easier.. Our minds can take huge and sustained pressure, if the cues it is receiving are not weighted in resistance, resistance being negativity , negativity being pain or leading to pain.. Prioritizing Yourself: The Key to Reducing Chaos As a psychotherapist, I often see how a lack of self-priority leads to chaos in our lives. When we constantly put others before ourselves, it can result in stress, burnout, and a sense of losing control. The Chaos of Neglecting Self-Priority üå™Ô∏è Increased Stress: Without boundaries, we take on too much, leading to overwhelming stress. üï∞Ô∏è Time Mismanagement: Prioritizing others leaves little time for our own needs, causing disorganization. üíî Emotional Exhaustion: Constantly giving to others without replenishing ourselves leads to emotional fatigue. üòî Feeling Less Than: We may feel less valued and work extra hard to prove our worth, often without realizing it. The Power of Self-Priority üåü Improved Well-Being: Self-care boosts mental and physical health, making you more resilient. üßò Greater Focus: Prioritizing yourself helps you stay productive and reduces chaos. ‚ù§Ô∏è Enhanced Relationships: When well-rested and emotionally balanced, you can give more to your relationships. How to Prioritize Yourself üìÖ Schedule Self-Care: Make time for activities that replenish you, like exercise and hobbies. üó£Ô∏è Set Boundaries: Learn to say "no" to overextending commitments. Communicate your limits clearly. üõå Rest and Recharge: Ensure you get enough sleep and take breaks to recharge. üßò Mindfulness Practice: Incorporate mindfulness to stay grounded and connected to your needs. Imagine a professional who always puts work and others first, leading to burnout. By prioritizing self-care, they can bring more focus and calm to their life, positively impacting their work and personal relationships. Making the Choice Remember, giving yourself more allows you to give more to the world around you. Prioritizing yourself is not selfish; it's essential for a balanced, fulfilling life. My inbox is always open for those ready to explore how to prioritize themselves and reduce chaos in their lives. Enjoy the day you create. "I'm afraid to slow down", a full-time working mum told me a few days ago. . I get it. . Being busy is familiar. Achieving is rewarded and celebrated. Doing gives you the feeling of being productive, therefore worthy of attention and recognition. . This way of living though means being stuck in the stress response. The stress response is a chemical reaction your body initiates (by releasing cortisol and adrenaline) when you perceive a threat. . A treat can be anything from you being face to face with a tiger üêØ OR you rushing to get the last train home (your brain doesn't know the difference!) . Being constantly in stress mode isn't sustainable and we all intuitively know it. Then, why some people are afraid to slow down? . My guess (and it's not an absolute truth) is because of the FEAR TO FEEL. . When you rest, you give time and space to your thoughts, emotions, problems, feelings, beliefs to come up to the surface. That can be unpleasant or even painful. Since we're wired for pleasure, the mind will do everything it takes to bring you away from pain. . Keeping busy can be a simple and effective way to distract you from the feelings you don't want to feel (it's fascinating how smart the mind is, isn't it?) . Unfortunately suppressing your feelings or ignoring your emotions won't let them go away. It'll actually exacerbate them. . The best path to become the healthier version of yourself, feeling more centred and good in your body is to learn how to feel the feelings. . This approach isn't easy and that's why I'm here to help! üëØ‚ôÇÔ∏è . I recently had the privilege of helping a client overcome a severe case of burnout. Like many people he'd transitioned to substantially working from home but he had allowed the line between work and home life to blur, overwhelming him. Before Covid he'd been used to commuting to work for about an hour each way and had therefore kept to a similar routine but working instead. As a result he worked a minimum 10 hour days, had constant meetings, didn't take breaks and to meet his targets often worked late into the evening. He was experiencing overwhelming fatigue, low motivation, trouble sleeping and a constant state of stress. Together we set out a plan for him focused on: 1. Recognising Triggers: Recognising what the contributing factors are and knowing what to do when you see them. 2. Implementing Self-Care Routines: Putting his needs first and prioritising his mental, physical and emotional wellbeing. We introduced daily practices such as movement breaks, mindfulness meditation and physical exercise to restore balance. 3. Setting Boundaries: We created 10 boundaries and later expanded this further to 15, such as setting clear work hours, taking a lunch break and learning to say no. Establishing healthy boundaries and communicating them to colleagues was crucial in preventing future burnout. 4. Creating a Support System: We focused on building a network of supportive colleagues, friends, and family members to lean on during tough times. 5. Planning for the Future: Setting him up to win, how to bounce back if you have broken a boundary and using his time for the things that matter to him. It took time to cut through the self-programming he was running and to embed new and healthier habits, clear boundaries and a growth mindset but through consistent effort he was able to regain his energy, passion and zest for life. His transformation was amazing to see and a testament to the power of taking positive steps towards mental and emotional wellbeing. If you or someone you know is struggling with burnout, remember that recovery is possible. Feel free to reach out‚Äîlet‚Äôs work together to reclaim your vitality and joy! #BurnoutRecovery #LifeCoaching #SelfCare #Burnout

Have you ever felt like you're stuck in a never-ending funk? Do you find yourself wondering why your energy levels are constantly low, no matter how much coffee you drink? Tired of feeling disconnected from your work and relationships? A few years ago, I hit a low point. Work sucked, my relationships were a mess, and I felt awful every day. Sound familiar? Like many of us, I was hesitant to seek professional help. Instead, I dove headfirst into research, determined to find answers on my own. That's when I stumbled upon some fascinating neuroscience (a study of how human brains work) that changed everything. It turns out, the culprits behind my persistent low mood weren't some deep-seated issues or major life events. They were hiding in plain sight ‚Äì small, everyday habits that were slowly draining my brain's energy and resilience. Here are just a few examples of what I discovered: Starting my day with a social media scroll (hello, anxiety!) Skipping breakfast or relying on sugary snacks (hello, mood swings!) Pushing through fatigue instead of taking breaks (hello, burnout!) These micro-habits, and others like them, were rewiring my brain for negativity and exhaustion without me even realizing it. The good news? Once I identified these sneaky energy zappers, I could start making small, manageable changes. And let me tell you, the results were nothing short of transformative. If this sounds like you, you're not alone. We're all trying to figure out this work-life thing, often without realizing how our daily choices affect us. Want to feel better and get your spark back? Are you able to switch off at weekends and relax? I'll be honest with you - I used to be the person who worked six days a week, late evenings and struggled to not constantly look at my phone to check work emails and socials. üôà I was a victim of 'busyness' and a self confessed 'workaholic'. üò´ It took a long time to change those habits. Firstly, I had to understand why I was doing it (having been ill for 12 years in earlier life and not being able to work full time or do what I wanted drove a feeling of needing to 'prove' myself). I also had a limiting belief that doing nothing or relaxing was lazy. I started to work on changing my mindset first and then impelement small steps to make change. üôÇ Here's the thing - if you try and change too much too soon, you won't succeed as it's too much for our brains and bodies to deal with. üß† There's a reason that we need to do thinigs slowly striving for small, actionable and achieveable steps. üë£ Gradually, I learned how to relax and switch off and in time, I was able to hugely reduce my working hours by taking the pressure off. Nowadays, I LOVE switching off at the weekends and that time is sacred to me. üòä And guess what?
